description: Great sushi...nice place. Sit at the bar so you can watch them make your sushi rolls.
author: Cristina P.

description:
I must have caught them on an off-day.  I found the sushi portions to be small, the cut of the maguro to include a little bit of that stringy toughness, and the rice to be a bit dry.  The decor is no-frills, and the restrooms so-so.  However the service was friendly and prompt.  I may try this another time before I really make up my mind.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Wanted to try out new ownership for awhile. I was not disappointed. Several things changed for better or for worse:

* Decor of the place changed drastically. New owners gave the restaurant a face lift, literally. Ceilings have been raised, new light fixtures, new paint, new furniture, new art work. New Mikaku does not look anything like old Mikaku. This appeals to many patrons.

* Prices have gone up. Understandably. Have to recoup capital expenditures.

* Portions decreased. See point above.

* Surprisingly, food tastes as good as with previous owners. And that's why I will come back. 

Very convinient location on the same block with Sutter-Stockton garage. Walk here or come by car and pay $3 for 2 hours in the garage. Usually, $3 will buy you about 25 minutes if parking at the meter on the street.
author: Tatyana S.

description:
What a FIND!  Notably a best kept secret located smack in front of china town's green gates (what's that thing called anyway?).

Sushi as this o schooler likes it, white aromatic rice, fatty/toro- grade fish perfectly balanced with some garnish but not over-the-top fancy.  Just clean, delicious and reasonably priced.  The steamed egg and chicken over rice is aaaaaahhhh.....  a comfort food lover's dream.  Gotta go back to try their soup.

Happy Hour, woo hoo.

Top 40 plays in the background, friendly smiling service, open LATE, safer street for group of gals to hang out late.
author: Surai J.

description:
There sure are slim pickings for lunch selections Downtown. I like Mikaku for sashimi and they are reasonably priced. The lack of stars is due to incredibly slow service (every single time!) and the rest of their food. 

Their lunch combo is okay but please do not get the Chicken Donburi. It was a bunch of fatty, scary-looking chicken with rice.
author: Karen S.

description:
A night out in San Fran could begin with a pregame here, especially if you're rolling out with a lot of people. Prices are reasonable, food is decent, and the place is not at all crowded after 8 PM. Mikaku's owner (Jin?) was really hospitable - some of the guys we went with were regulars - and brought us complimentary garlic fries, soju shots, and cheesecake for the birthday girl. We did sake bombs and generally acted obnoxious. I think the girls next to us hated us. :) Basically, you can get halfway to wasted here before even hitting a single bar. 

The food was nothing spectacular. I personally wouldn't take someone here on a date because I didn't find anything to be particularly special, but the prices are very good ($5 - $10 per appetizer, $10 - $15 per roll). I shared a tonkotsu appetizer with the birthday girl that was alright. She also ordered two baked rolls that I liked and would recommend. I think one of them was called the china doll?
author: Shirley H.

description: We went there with a group of 6 for work lunch. We had a reservation and were seated right away. It was pretty empty when we got there a little before noon but it was pretty much full when we left an hour later. The food was good and fast, the waitress was very nice and attentive. We had the tempura and dumpling appetizers and I had the roll combo for lunch. It was three types of rolls, salad and miso soup. I am by no means an expert on sushi but I liked everything
author: Christine H.

description:
Really nice owner who waits on me personally.

I love when the sushi chef yells out 'NEW CUSTOMER!"...
author: Margaret L.

description:
OK, my last review got removed.
So, I'll make it short this time.
Owner Changed! Everything Changed!
100% Chinese now!
It is under new management.

Please see the date of Toro E's review. 1/05/2007.
3 years ago! And using the same photos he took.
That's BS!
Bad Sushi here!

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THE PLACE, PERIOD!
author: Nobu K.

description:
If you're working late then you want something tasty that won't bloat you to the max. For me, that's always sushi and I'll usually get delivery to the office. Today, however, I decided to roam about and give takeout a try.

From Mikaku I got some basic sushi:
- Maguro nigiri
- Tekka maki
- Salmon skin hand roll

The chef made it quickly, the fish was fresh and price was reasonable. I can't complain, and I was actually pretty happy. I'll probably come back again, thanks Mikaku!
author: Ayumi Y.

description: Im not a yelper, but when I go to a place enough (such as this one) I have to jump on and give a review.  All I have to say is....super fresh, great deal, great service.  The sign outside said "wild caught japanese hamachi", my favorite, so I had to jump it.  After 8 pieces of amazing hamachi and 2 super fresh scallop hands rolls, this place is now 3 for 3 on my lunch visits.  I cant wait to visit for dinner, as this is my top 3 places in the bay area to eat sushi.  See you soon!
author: chris p.

description:
After posting my review, I received a message (as others have, apparently) from the owner's daughter, "colette p."  This was her message: 
"ay b*tch dont be talking sh*t about my moms restaurant. ima f*ck your a** up if u come back and f*ck up ur son. u better be cool. who the f*ck are u to talk sh*t? do u waitress? do u know how hard it is to do so? b*tch you playing. dont step into my familys restaurant again before i f*ck both you up."

Interesting approach to a business.  And in response to your question, colette, Yes, I do know how hard it is to waitress.  I did it for 4 years to help put myself through college.  And trust me - I won't bother stepping into your family's restaurant again.
author: Cristina S.

description: My boyfriend and I came here for some sushi and it was pretty good. More points for prompt service and no waiting! The China Gate Roll is good (and spicy!)
author: Jacie N.

description: Great service.  However, I've had better sushi.  In addition, this place does not have misago (what kind of sushi restaurant doesn't have misago?).  If you're looking for a place to go for a quick happy hour bite, this is your place.  If you're looking for a great-tasting full sushi meal, it's probably not your best bet.
author: Virginia C.

description: There is a tiny cockroach in the sake, after I told the waiter, he is like. "Oh, that is just a fly." WTF?! Does it make it ok to have a fly in the sake as long as it's not a cockroach?!
author: Tyler C.

description:
The absolute worst place I have eaten, and when I say the worse I am not talking about just sushi restaurants, literally the worst restaurant I have ever eaten in my life! 

I went there today (and yes you nasty waitress I hope you remember me from lunch!!!!) and I understand it's busy, got it, but why would you give me and my friend our hot sake and then take another freakin 10 minutes to big the beer? And I kept asking her where our drinks were, she would smile say yes, and still not bring them over!!! 

No big deal there's no way I'd bother to take the time to yelp if this was the biggest deal.... the problem was how horrific my lunch was. I ordered the chef's choice sushi, and i almost started to laugh when they brought it to me. Ten dollars for 4 pieces off sushi and a shrimp... OK I still wouldn't have bothered to take my time to yelp... It looked like a four year old took out his play scissors and made a brave attempt to cut the fish. The fish was jagged and see through, one piece was kinda cut in half... 

I got the waitress and asked for the menu so i could order something else because it was so bad, she smiled blankly brought the menu didn't ask what the problem was and I would have ordered something else if it hadn't taken ten more minutes to come back to me!!! 

Then the same deal at the end couldn't get the change back from the bill, no one asked me about my meal even though half the sushi was on my plate (OK so there were only 4 pieces to start with) ugh... The place blows...
author: patti k.

description: This is one place I will not forget.  The freshness is key and they nailed it that day.
author: Ryan K.

description:
Came in an off hour, so restaurant was empty. It's conveniently located near Union Square. Sushi is OK. Not great, not bad. Fish is fresh, so cant complaint. Cucumber ring roll was interesting and very spice, just the way I like it. 

But... The music was kinda weird, for a sushi place at least. Enya like songs, which accompanied by my beer on a rainy Sunday evening, were nearly putting me to sleep! Until of course I would take a bite a spicy piece of sushi!! Repeat: sushi very spicy!! 

If you are nearby, you can try. But not sure if it's worth driving just to come here.
author: Michel A.

description: Literally the worst Japanese food I've ever had. Fish isn't fresh, actually slightly bitter. Sushi rice is so rare.
author: Kris Z.

description: Very good sushi and great service, but the portions were not worth the price. Other than that it was a meal well enjoyed when I was having an outing with my roomie.
author: Joji V.

description: These guys are great! Really good sushi and Japanese beers that are ice cold! Friendly smiles and great staff make for a nice and refreshing environment for a nice lunch.
author: Nathan S.

description:
I love Sushi and constantly try out new places. This place was great.
In terms of the Fish itself. It was perfect. Every single piece of Nigiri, Sashimi, and the roll was perfect except for one. The salmon was an 8.5 out of 10. The rest were 10s. The Edemame was served warm with salt. Perfect. The Korean Nigori Sake was bad, but that's not their fault. The waitress should know better to shake the Sake, open it, and pour it. She didn't do any of that, but the Sushi Chef saw this, came by and did it for us. The decor and environment was very nice, and clean. The Price was totally reasonable. If I could give this place four and half stars, deducting for some minor service issues, I would but since it's really about the fish, it was great.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
My friends and I stumbled accross this Sushi place as we were looking for another one. We decided we were too hungry to keep looking for the other place so we decided to try this one. We were so glad we did. We had the best dining experience. 

We had a great waitress that was very knowledgable about Sake and she helped us pick out some really great Sake. 

The food was really great. I has some fantastic Sushi rolls that I can't remember the name of now, sorry. I remember one had baked Salmon on it, yum, that one was so good. 

The music playing was a compilation of hits from the 90's. We had the best time trying to remember the artist name and just reminiscing about the music. It was seriously the best playlist ever!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
I came here for lunch with my grandmother and my sister and we all  LOVED it.

We ordered soft shell crab, hamachi sashimi, uni sushi, rainbow roll, and the nuclear cruncy roll and were impressed by the quality of all the fish. Everything was really fresh and the presentation was wonderful.

The staff here were very nice and very attentive. My sister took awhile to decide what to order but they were very patient with us. And they came back every once in a while to make sure we were enjoying our food and if we needed anything else.

I though that this place being in downtown would be difficult to get parking, but there was a parking garage right around the corner, and the pricing was not bad.

I definitely recommend this restaurant, the have really good quality sashimi and sushi.
author: Alicia W.

description: Happy hour rolls!   Sure, the selection isn't fabulous, but I have simple tastes - tuna roll, salmon avocado roll.  The fish is fresh.  I wouldn't pay non-happy hour prices, but it's a great dinner stop on the way home.
author: Sona P.

description: Delicious!! I had the china wall roll and it was amazing! Happy hour beer for $2. Our waiter didn't seem to like his job much but other than that it was a great experience. I would eat here again and recommend it to others.
author: Chantill S.

description: Lots of different rolls with unique flavors. Felt a bit ripped off with the edamame, it was only half a bowl. I thought they trying to prank me.
author: Tony A.

description:
Been here for lunch after a work out on a weekend...not bad. Cute little interior. Ok service and good sushi rolls. 
It is in U.Sq.. right next to Lulu Lemon, ha! bonus!=)..makes the food taste better...j/k/.
They were playing some good R&B tunes, a little old school-ish but yea hit the spot!
I dont have anything else to say about this place. I dont think i will go back, it was ok but nothing different or special.
author: C A.

description: This is becoming a standard post-happy hour drunken sushi place (as if there were any other kinds). The prices are a little high, but nothing absurd -- and hot house sake remains a good deal. I usually go with some sort of sashimi and haven't been disappointed.
author: Adam D.

description: Great food and friendly staff! Sit at the bar and the sushi chef might treat you to some free sake or fish! He's awesome and hilarious. I would definitely come here again.
author: Emily L.

description:
DIRTY and RUDE STAFF ... I just left this restaurant five minutes ago without having my dinner. The waiter gave me a menu as I sat at the table. There were rice pieces sticking in menu!! How GROSS is that !! I did not make a big deal and grabed another menu from the table next to me. 

Then, I ordered a house salad with my food and there was HAIR in it. I told the waiter, he took the plate and without saying anything brought me a new one. He did not ask me whether I wanted another salad or anything else. He brought another salad and I told him that I don't want another one any more. Then he SMASHED the salad plates and left my table without saying anything!! Seriously ?!? 

WORST SERVICE EVER!! No surprise they have only three tables full on a Friday night.
author: Gonca G.

description:
I really like this sushi place. I have been here several times for lunch when
I am working at the SF Chamber of Commerce. This is a great location right down from China town which is nice to walk down the streets after you eat. I ordered the salmon sashimi which was fresh but wasn't enough so I ordered a philly roll also. The staff was polite and helpful. I will be back
next week when I get back from So-cal.There is a place in Anaheim called Tokyo Love that reminded me of this place. Good Sushi.
author: Tommy S.

description: Visiting SF for the first time, found this great sushi place down the block from out hotel. Great service, great happy hour, great atmosphere. Will definitely come back when I'm here again :)
author: Tay J.

description:
This has got to be the sexiest Japanese restaurant in the city. The first time I came here, they played non-stop nineties R&B sex music (seriously, for two straight hours at least). My friend and I were dining after happy hour and so we had a good buzz going and were cracking up the whole time singing along to all the songs we remembered from the nineties. It was actually a very fun dining experience. The second time I came here, they played more contemporary pop music so the amusement wore off but the food was just as good if not better than the first time. Love it here.

Highly recommended: Nabeyaki udon and sake baby!
author: Jenny T.

description: My husband and I sit at the sushi bar and the chef let us know that he was too tired to do much so we should probably order teriyaki chicken or something else from the kitchen. Lame.
author: Nori S.

description: pretty good sushi and udon. You should come at happy hours 5-7pm, great menu
author: Suabot J.

description:
I would write more, but I am enjoying the warm food coma.

The normal menu is good, but if you get things labeled special #2, etc, that are not on the menu they are spectacular!

And the price for that much fish, of that quality, in that incredible a roll, best deal on sushi I've had in at least a year.
author: Boris K.

description:
Had a great meal last night with a few friends.  There are a lot of great sushi restaurants in the city, but Mikaku is one of the standouts.  Small plates were very well done.  We had agedashi tofu, goma ae, oshinko, and chicken karaage.  Prob the best karaage I've had in the city.  

Next we had hamachi kama.  One of my favorites and a good yardstick for quality of a restaurant.  It was the biggest I've seen and cooked perfectly. mmmm....

Nigiri was very fresh.  some standouts included escolar, toro, uni, and the sabe.  Prices for the fish are pretty standard for high quality pieces.  Prices for beer are better than most and sake pretty standard.  Mikaku has a very good sake selection and the owner was able to teach us a few things about sake and recommended some killer selections.

Service was very good from server to owner to sushi chef.  Didn't sit at the sushi bar but would like to next time as the chef was super nice and entertaining as well.    Will definitely go back for another round.
author: Christopher Y.

description: I know it's happy hour and things are a bit cheaper... but it really doesn't mean you can get away with serving up crumbling fish scraps. The spicy tuna roll was barely edible. Would not recommend it unless it's happy hour and you are absolutely starving
author: Danni W.

description: For the price it was just okay.  They were kind of going for a minimalist thing, which is pretty cool, but the whole place has rather tepid vibes somewhere between business person and asian buffet.
author: Mike L.

description:
Last Fall my husband discovered this place. By the time we went to check it out, it was closed for renos. Kinda wished that I had gone before the renos and had written a bad review so someone could call me a "b*tch a*s sucka muthaf*cka", for some reason I find it highly amusing...

Anyhoos, I walk by this resto everyday on my way home. The new $5.50 lunch menu ads caught my eye so I finally stopped by. My lunch was a-Ok, nothing to write home about and certainly nothing that would cause one to be cussed out (damn!). The unagidon was alright. The spicy tuna was alright. The waiter offered me tea or water while I waited for my to go order - which I thought was cool. I waited about 10 mins for my order. It was nicely packed. All the other customers looked content - I don't think they'll get cussed out either (damn!).

I'd go back for lunch.
author: Kiristen R.

description: While spending the weekend in SF, we decided to check out Mikaku for dinner on a Sat night. We made an 8pm reservation and were sat right away. Our server was great, offering suggestions on his favorite rolls since we were undecided on what to order. I wish I could remember the names of them, but all 4 that we ordered were delicious and fresh. We were very impressed how fast they came out. Our only minor disappointment was the edamame- somewhat dry and not salted... But the sushi rolls more than made up for it. Great food, nice atmosphere and friendly service. We would definitely go back again.
author: Stefanie P.

description: Good Enough Sushi. Probably ate here more than any sushi place in the city. Not because it's the best, but because it stays open later and is reasonably tasty. Rolls are not too fancy. Stay away from salmon. Veggie rolls are good, like the caterpillar. They lack a good bento box option, but you can go elsewhere for that. Easy to get a seat at any time. Reasonable price. Only real gripe is not being treated like royalty even though I've been there more than enough times to be crowned king of any social network check-in. Where's my free appetizer??? :)
author: Steve T.

description: Sushi and service were excellent. They offer unique options plus excellent expected options, and they do not skimp on the quality of their fish. Also, reservations were not a necessity, which was an added bonus in SF on a Friday evening.
author: Becca M.

description: Wow. Happened to stand by the bar while waiting for a table and saw the guy drop a piece of fish on the floor and pick it up and put it right back in the cooler! Never thought it could get this bad :-) They got defensive when I confronted. Thankfully I hadn't ordered. Super Health hazard.
author: Karthick S.

description: Great happy hours. Delicious crunchy California roll. Best priced sushi around and tastes pretty good!
author: Finn F.

description:
I happen to stop by here a few weeksd ago on my first Saturday in the City. First of all the service and the music were great. The happy hour is amazing, half off all drinks!!! 

The food was great and the waitress had grat recommendations. I recommend if you are looking for great food, great service and amazing happy hour this is the place to be.
author: Luis C.

description: The sushi fish is not fresh, and the rice is hardened... and it's pretty expensive. The waitress never refilled my water glass. Not worth it at all
author: Shawn G.

description:
present - goodbye old mikaku?...hello happy hour?...poor service?...poor food?....flabbergasted...

4/22/07 - mikaku..situated center block isn't shy to boast attention...flappin' curtained "mikaku" awnin'..free standing signs displaying mikaku's offerings to patrons..... reminisce of small alleyway restaurants in asia....for it's a small-scale aged establishment..friendly..family like atmosphere....equally homemade feel to the delectable plates focusin' on flavor and pairing...balanced taste 'n' textures..

crispy..lightly battered asian pumpkin paired with sea salt...salt brings out the true sweetness...intensifying...enrich the true pumpkin taste....grilled duck with even textures of fat and poultry...warm..moist and meaty balance with simple salt to highlight the duck.....vinegary cold snapper fish....coldness lessens any "fishy" taste while keeping the delicate fish to al dente...enjoyable....warm simmered octopus with daikon..mixes the soft sweet gentle texture of the braised daikon with the chewy tougher texture of the octopus....harmony...each offerings delectable and different...keeping the palate entertained...

whiteboard menu appears to be the wise choice....sampling each item...great meal....from crispy fried battered oysters and crispy yet chewy yam cakes to thinly sliced sashimi platter and homemade soba noodles....beyond with sesame spinach to braised fatty pork with horseradish/mustard....mikaku didn't disappoint......drinkin' the night away with over 3 liters of sake....turned the dinner into a social conversin' evening with some honorable company...
author: Hen A.

description: Seems to be a staple on my way back to the East Bay. Decent food,sake bombers, and friendly staff. Too many tourists perhaps but it is Union Square I suppose.
author: Blake B.

description:
Lunch: Mikaku's $13.50 deluxe chirashi is unbeatable in taste for the price.  Chirashi is sashimi on top of sushi rice (chef makes it on sour-side! yipee! please, there is no such thing as sweet sushi rice): red snapper, squid, maguro, hamachi, maguro, tamago (homemade), salmon and saba.  Mikaku sprinkles shredded cucumber on top of rice, underneath sashimi, which adds a fresh flavor.  This is my lunch time staple.  Oh!  By the way, if you are the first 10 customers (i.e., get there before 11:45am) you get California rolls.  Chirashi always accompanied with little starter dish and miso soup. 

Dinner: Mikaku makes handpulled soba noodles.  It's good.  When you go here for dinner, just order off the dinner only white board menu by the sushi bar.  You can only get it at dinner time.  They won't budge about serving it at lunch.  Its actually a great jedi mind trick because whenever I have dinner at Mikaku and eat the stuff on the white board, I feel super lucky.  Loved the fried konnyaku, kabocha and duck.  

BY THE WAY, though Mikaku is listed under "Nob Hill," its just one block West and one block North from the Crocker Galleria.  Totally accessible to all FiDi workers.

Owner/Chef Ito-san is cool.
author: Wakako U.

description:
ok, before i stumbled across this place i ate all over union square as i am a sashimi fan.  I ate at Tsunami, Akiko's Sakana and Wayo, but I found their fish good, but pricy.  I am not a snob or a penny pincher, but if I can find a place with real good sushi, at a good price I am all for it.  
There is no REAL need to find a place with cool lighting, or a fancy decor.  As one person once told me, "sushi is fish and you can't get fresher than fresh so pick a place with a good price and good fish."
author: Jai D.

description:
I've gone in here before for a typical "sushi day"...

Today, I made the GRAVE mistake or ordering what I would consider as my "usual Japanese lunch"...

I ordered prawn tempura, rice, and gyoza...cost me $24.  It's double what I normally pay at my preferred spot!  I'm ok spending paying more for quality, but unfortunately...the prawns (if you can call it that) are so tiny, you'd think that they used the same shrimp that restaurants use for their shrimp cocktail.  The Gyoza...ergh.  For half the price, go to Niji at Crocker Galleria instead!
author: Morez G.

description:
If you're craving sushi in Union Square, Mikaku is a nice place to come across. During the weekdays, it's a busy lunch crowd. Service is efficient and the staff are friendly. You can be in and out pretty quickly, or linger.

The bento options are pretty solid and for the quality of fish, I'd say a pretty good deal. Or try one of their combos like I did yesterday - spicy tuna roll and tempura - for about $10. 

I wasn't wowed by Mikaku but hope to go back for a full-out sushi session. For a quick lunch or perhaps if you're visiting SF and our staying nearby, Mikaku is a good bet in the area.
author: Nish N.

description:
Pretty busy place on a Thursday evening. But warm ambiance and homey service. They serve sake and let you choose from a basket of different styles and shapes of sake cups-- a bit unusual.

Assorted sashimi was pretty good-- soft, light and not the too shiny slimy kind-- I like. Wakame soba was simple. Warm house sake was a bit stronger than what I normally have, almost made me feel tipsy-- or I was just drinking on an empty stomach at 9pm.

This is a good local joint without the unnecessary glamour and gives you a comfy and fuzzy feeling with B+ food. And the price was pretty inexpensive too.
author: T L.

description:
I made the mistake of taking the in-laws here after a bout of post-Thanksgiving Christmas shopping. The place appears to be run by one waitress (for about 45 patrons), and one sushi chef. Let's just say the whole process took more than a few hours. It took about 20 minutes just to get a sushi menu. Then another 15 minutes to get water. The wait goes on...
Of course, I expected after all of the wait (and it's not budget-priced), to be impressed with the quality of the sushi. Sadly, this was not the case. I have never seen such skimpy portions of flaccid refrigerated stale sushi in my life. Even Safeway does it better. Save yourself the money, and go to Safeway. 
This is the classic case of a place staying in business because of touristy foot traffic (right next to the gates of Chinatown), where it would have ceased to exist long ago if it were anywhere else.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Service was untimely and unprofessional. Sushi subpar. Quality of fish also inferior (not rancid, just didn't have the sushi grade flavor). Most rolls were uncreative; we ordered the few creative ones on the menu and were severely disappointed with the execution. (i.e. tuna special started w/ a rather flavorless tuna & heavy fish texture and finished w/ a thick wad of cream cheese. Spicy scallop had huge mounds of scallop pieces drowned in about 4oz of a "spicy" mayo w/ no kick, just an aftertaste reminiscent of an expired dried spice cabinet.)

Will not return and would not recommend. (The only two sushi restaurants I tried in San Fran on my recent trip bombed.  We did find a great one in Sausalito called Sushi Ran.)
author: Rebekah S.

description: I have had many good meals here but tonight the service was awful. Dirty plates piled up, could not get a server. Place only half full. Fish is fresh and well prepared. Would like to give more stars but service is an important part of the experience.
author: Mitch M.

description:
Very authentic reasonably priced Japanese food. Ordered the lunch Chirashi for $11 bucks and really filled me up. The big perk about this place is that they advertise no MSG which is rare for any Asian restaurant.

Don't come here to order rolls or expecting that there will be any selection of rolls what-so-ever! Come here only if you want to eat nigiri or sashimi. My preggo sis ordered a bento box b/c she's preggo and from what I saw had a nice variety of small dishes. The noodle salad was a nice unique touch. 

Compared to the busy city atmosphere the inside was a different more relaxing family-owned atmosphere. Come here if you want a  real portion of nigiri rice (shari), not the fat-boy portion they give you at buffets to make you fuller faster.
author: becky s.

description:
Japanese sake/sushi bar
Between Union Square and Chinatown
Nice setting, not fancy.
Miso soup was hot and good.
Lunches were bento boxes with one or two entrees (plus salad, pickled ginger, and white rice). Teriyaki chicken had a lighter, but tasty sauce (less ajinimoto). Tempura was good. Sashimi was very good. 
Super green tea ice cream
Nice selection of sakes. Have a happy hour.
Service needs a little work e.g., the timing of serving all the dishes at the proper times
Clean bathroom
author: Rosquete B.

description:
Craving sushi and some sake bombs, myself and 4 girlfriends stumbled upon this joint late Saturday night. 

Posted outside was happy hour 10-midnight. Perfect! Upon entrance, the place was rocking some ke$ha and we were greeted by friendly waitstaff excited for some patrons. 

$2 sake bombs! Our waitress and the entire staff joined in our excitement, chanting with us as chopsticks and beer spewed in all directions. Within seconds, several waitresses rushed to clean up the mess and provide the next round. 

The sushi itself was very good and with reasonable prices. We ordered a slew of rolls- honorable mention goes to the sweet potato roll. Sweet potato tempura rolled in ricey goodness dipped in eel sauce = delish.

Natasha the owner was the reason we would come back. She brought us a bottle of sake on the house and even joined in our fun, schooling all of us in chugging down the beer. 

Not sure what all these other reviews are about but my girls and I had a fantastic experience!
author: Jesse L.

description:
Though not fancy to look at, Mikaku's generic sushi bar decor belies the unusual attention to detail apparent in the food.

At Mikaku everyday  menu items are elevated by the quality of the ingredients, and the well balanced seasoning.

I go at lunch for the thoughfully prepared Chirashi, and the bento is always a delicious option.

- Sushi Geek Notes _

Traditionally, the 4 markers to judge a sushi bar by are rice, tamago, mackerel and the way the eel is sauced.

Mikaku has very good rice, well seasoned, and correct in temperature and Tamago  that is neither too sweet nor too firm. The eel and house cured mackerel are both very good.
author: Stellah D.

description:
Otherwise forgettable, is Yelp-worthy (at least by moi) soley as a decent stand-by considering the dearth of reasonable sit-down lunch options in FiDi.

When you want more than a sandwich or takeout but don't want to shell out $25-$30 for lunch (what am I, made of money?) - Mikaku will do. Nothing spectacular, just your standard teriyaki-donburi-tempura & sushi offerings executed fairly well...like I said, pickings are slim in the area, so I'll probably be back. 

It's all relative...
author: Kathy Y.

description: Placed an order to go for vegetarian rolls and ended up with all fish rolls. The guy taking the order was pretty much out of it. They don't seem like the most focused bunch of guys there. I would check your order before you leave.
author: Patty Boy X.

description:
I got takeout for lunch here this past week.

Sushi quality was pretty atrocious. Nigiris were stale and flaking apart and the rolls were done poorly. To top it off, they dont give you the soup part of the lunch combo to go because they "dont have to-go soup containers". Really? Even though I paid for it? What gives?!

If you're in the mood for sushi, skip this place and go to Akiko's Sushi around the corner.
author: Didi R.

description:
This is a vegetarian review.  I have no idea what the "real" sushi is like.

Fantastic selection of vegetarian sushi, and everything tasted fresh and delicious!  It was also one of the cheapest lunches I've had in the financial district.  And it wasn't too crowded, yay!
author: Rachael S.

description:
Not spectacular sushi, but speedy, friendly service.  Prices are super-reasonable, and the tea has this unique, smoky flavor to it.  They even threw in complimentary California rolls for being there early.  

We went here because Akiko's (on Bush) was closed.  *sigh*
author: Evan G.

description:
I haven't had the sushi, so this review is not based on that. It was a cold day when my friend and I were shopping. She mentioned that we should go to this place since it was reasonably priced and the food was decent. We had an avocado roll, which was generic, followed by an appetizer of the tempura, and two bowls of udon. Firstly, the tempura was absolutely terrible, but then again, I only ate the shrimp part. The batter was absolutely disgusting, but not as bad as the shrimp which was chewy and flavorless. The soup was steaming but it lacked everything else.

What was most disappointing was the lack of service. There were at four or five tables. One or two waitresses. And it took forever for the food, the refill of water, making sure the meal was okay.

I'd rather go to Sushi Rika down the street. At least, they give you a ton of stuff in your soup and makes you feel satisfied. 

The only plus point is this: the prices are very reasonable for Japanese food. The soup was at least $2.00 less. Too bad it's just mediocre and boring!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
My roommate and I were just kicking around on Halloween day. Both of us wanted some decent sushi but didn' t want to walk all the way back to Sakana which is usually our default sushi place around union square. Walking by Mikaku, we had memory of the previous Japanese restaurant which was only a so-so place and we were contemplating whether we should go in. After looking around and the menu for a while (it's kinda quiet inside), we decided to take the risk and give it a try.

It turns out to be a good surprise. The atmosphere is fun and warm. Everyone were dressing up for Halloween, even the chef.  The Japanese lady, Natasha, gave us 2 bottles of free sake after we talked about how hard it is to find good fresh uni. At the end, she convinced me to order some uni and we ordered 2 orders! She also gave us some ikura to try but I am really not a big fan of it so couldn't up sell us with this one :D

Now we have another place to have some fresh decent sushi around downtown.
author: Hinling Y.

description: Everything was okay. Ate here for lunch 4/29/11.  It was only my co-worker and I, we got seated right away.  Water was put on the table promptly.  Ordered the 2 item lunch bento, the Tonkasu and Teriyaki Beef.  The Tonkasu was good but small 5 piece portion.  The Teriyaki Beef was good!  The portion size on the beef was better.  I wasn't really full after the meal.  The meal cost $10.50 or so.  Co-worker also had the 2 item lunch bento he got Teriyaki Chicken and California rolls.  The chicken and the rice was dry.  He wasn't satisfied at all with the food.  Not somewhere I would come back to again.
author: Jon L.

description: Went here on a cold SF night for some Udon noodles and it hit the spot. The serving was so large that I had plenty for lunch the next day. Can't complain about the service since we had a nice server. For being in such a touristy area, Mikaku is a surprisingly good place. I would come back here to try the sushi.
author: Amy N.

description:
I am feeling under the weather, so a hot bowl of Udon soup sounded in order. Silly me, I didn't look up a good place before lunch. So I stumbled on this place... 

I wanted to get an avo-kappa maki and miso soup but they said it would be 20 minutes, so I went with the original idea of udon soup. Fine. It comes with veggie tempura, normally a good thing. 

I drink my green tea and eat the cold noodles with mayo (blech) whatching the single sushi chef work. The fish didn't look delicious or particularly well stored. Everything had a old world sanitation feel to it. He was still fun to watch. And everyone around me seemed to be enjoying their sushi. 

My soup came. It smelled like sheep poop. I'm serious! Somehow the blend of fish broth and buckwheat = sheep poop. I grew up around them... I'm not making it up. Luckily once I sprinkled on a generous portion of nanami togarashi, my nose got stuffed and I couldn't really smell anymore. The flavor was good, the noodles a bit over done. 

Unfortunately the tempura was only warm and soggy, so I didn't really eat much of it. They didn't provide any dipping sauce, so I just dipped it in the soup, which made my soup kinda greasy. I ate all the broth but had to forgo most of the noodles. 

Not a good experience. I'd give them another shot based on other reviews. I'll keep you updated. 

PS this was my horoscope today: Don't be so impulsive today, for your quick response is not likely to be your best. Remember, your intuition might be a bit off, so instead of trusting your feelings, keep coming back to the facts. Take enough time to think about the consequences of your actions before you do anything that could land you in trouble.
author: Elsa E.

description:
bottom line: slow service, tasty and light food.

we came here to grab a quick bite late at night and didn't really feel like sushi, so we opted for the chicken donburi.  the chicken and sauce were surprisingly tasty, yet not too heavy.  the order also came with miso soup and salad, a nice bonus.  obviously can't speak for the sushi, but would be open to ordering donburi again.  restaurant is a bit packed and service was fairly slow.
author: Aaron T.

description:
This was one of those places where I scratched my head... What to write? 2 dishes shined, 3 dishes were just OK, and one dish was so bad that between the three of us we were trying to pawn it off on each other. We couldn't even tell what it was-- the waitress had forgotten one of the orders, so we were confused over what came out versus what we were still waiting on.

Really good:
- fried, salted pumpkin
- braised soy sauce pork

OK:
- noodles
- including the house-made soba... a little harder and less chewy-toothy-smooth than I would have liked.  (Maybe house-made yesterday??)

Bad:
- yam cake sashimi. Maybe I don't know enough about Japanese cuisine beyond noodles and sushi to get it, but this had a weird texture (think jellyfish without the fishiness) and was generally flavorless. What's the point?

A bit pricey considering the quality of the food. Within that proximity, I way prefer Sanraku just a couple blocks away...
author: Amy D.

description: 1 star for great happy hour prices, 1 star for yummy goyza. Not the freshest rolls in town, but if your in need of a quick sushi fix just beware of the imitation crab.
author: Mallory M.

description:
I held off on writing a review on this place for a couple of reasons: 1. The food has not always been good here; 2. But it is the one place I can down some sake and walk home after...  I find myself in a strange position...  Do I write a bad review on a place I will continue to show my face at...  or do I write a good review when I only like the food there half of the times...?  

Last night, after an outstanding meal at the sushi bar (I normally take a table), I think Mikaku has redeemed itself...  I am now writing a review on this place with much understanding and appreciation.

My relationship with this place started out of convenience.  Based on the sashimi that came with my lunch/dinner bento, I had been very reluctant to order any real sushi items.  However, many of their Japanese dishes, such as tofu in hot broth, homemade soba, salt duck, and other Japanese "diner" food have always been very good.  The special board will tell you: Clams in Sake, Creamy Daikon Soup... etc.  So I basically avoid sushi there.  

Then last night I had this urgent need for some sushi.  I came here, and it was packed with Japanese businessmen.  I sat at the sushi bar and ordered what I could: Black Cod, White Tuna, Yellowtail and Amaebi.  I had my fingers crossed, hoping that by paying more the quality of the fish would be (much needed) better than the bento quality.  

I was NOT disappointed.  In addition to the tasty fish, I noticed how well trained the chef was.  Very skilled, precise--- an old school chef who went through the whole tutelage beginning with rice washing  long before he was allowed to touch the fish.  I almost felt sad that as good as he was, he had to make those silly spicy tuna and California rolls. 

After a very satisfying meal, he asked me how the food was.  I said, "Delicious," then added, "you are a very good sushi chef."  Instead of a humble nod, he smiled proudly, as if giving me props for recognizing it.  I also suggested that I'd wish to see more seafood items, such as aji and scallops.  He shook his head and explained that he did do that in the past, but no one ordered it.  I turned my head and saw the Japanese businessmen who busied themselves away with the food...  Some of food items I had never seen before.  And I recalled that this place was constantly hit by the traffic of Japanese travelers...  At that moment I decided to make good rapport with this nice sushi chef.  I want what those Japanese men are eating.  With that said, Mikaku shall see me back very soon.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
For lunch, I ordered the Mikaku Special and was pleased with the generous portion of food, given the modest price.

Said food, however, was not very good.  From the overly salty miso soup to the chewy tempura, I wished my dining companion and I hadn't opted for Japanese.
author: Marcus C.

description:
In response to the comment below, I was also part of the group of girls looking for some sushi on Saturday night.  

Highlight of the night was the $2 sake bombs.  I think we had close to 6 each!  Food was great and the service was very prompt.  Definitely will be going back here again!!

Oh, and kudos to the sweet potato tempura roll!
author: Charlene B.

description: Amazing sashimi; fresh fish, large portions, reasonable prices, friendly chefs & servers. I have been here twice now, late. Love it!
author: Mark S.

description:
If you wanna talking about authentic Japanese restaurant, Mikaku is the place.  They have a lot of authentic dishes and the restaurant itself look authentic, too.

I've been there several times.  I love chirashi.  They give you lots of fish, and they are all fresh.  And the sushi rice is just right.  Not too sour, not too sweet and not cold like they just took out from the refrigerator.  I can't stand sour sushi rice; the vinegar smell hit my nose.  And if the sushi rice is too cold, make me wanna go to the bathroom.  So, it's important that the quality of sushi rice for me.

And you should check out the white board "dinner time only".  One of my favorites is homemade buckwheat noodle.  Very smooth, not like soba noodle from super markets.  And dip-in sauce is just amazing!!  Not too salty, not too sweet.  And they give you "soba-yu" afterwards which you suppose to pour in the dip-in sauce and drink it!  Wild, ha?  But it was good.

This place is not fancy or hip, but if you wanna have a real Japanese meal, you should go Mikaku.
author: Mike N.

description:
Quick service during lunch rush hour is always a plus. i was surprised - had the spicy tuna roll and tempura roll. spicy tuna was spicy but fresh - and it came with 12 pieces.

miso was a teeny bit odd though... really salty. i'd go back for sure :)
author: laura f.

description:
Very ordinary restaurant with mediocre food and sub-par waitresses. Maybe my friends and I were just exhausted from a long day, but none of us thought this place stood out.

I had the nagiri deluxe, so 12 different nagiris. Somewhat pricy for the quantity, and the fish didn't taste 100% fresh, but that isn't to say it wasn't decent. Also had the sake.

Would I return? Probably not - there're plenty of alternatives in the city.

Time: dinner
Food: nagiri deluxe
Cost: $20/person after tax and tip
author: Jack W.

description: Me and my friend used to go here like i say 2x a week when it was under the older management. Things have shifted and definitely looks better now but i miss the food that was served before. So idk if im going to come back any time soon. Probably not anymore.
author: Nikka L.

description:
I love how authentic this place is from the perspective of lots of Japanese folks eating there even though it's right in a weird spot kinda Union Square/Chinatown-ish and all.

The specials board is written in Japanese and Engrish although at lunch they didn't apply.  The udon I had was nice and tasty with a good stock and I went ahead and got a few pieces of nigiri too.  Not amazing, but then I didn't expect that here.  The fish was pretty good and decently priced, but I think this place specializes more in the traditional dishes.

Anyhow, a nice spot for a quick lunch - I will have to check it out at dinner as well!
author: Gene X.

description:
Wow....this place easily has the best sushi I have ever had....period!!
I've been to a lot of sushi places and tried all kinds of sushis.  Yet another fusion style sushi place I love. I have been here a couple times. each time bringing different sets of friends. one set had a first time sushi eater who enjoyed their sushi. The other friend also agreed it was some of the best sushi they have ever had,
The second time I went I brought my friends from Hawaii (born and raised) and they were blown away. They could not believe the sushi was so good....and they are from Hawaii!! I was surprised to hear them say that considering Hawaii easily has the freshest fish and ingredients available in the US.
Each time I have gone every roll was presented exceptionally well. I love it!!
Oh...they also serve you hot tea before the meal.
For desert we had mochi ice cream. we had all three flavors, strawberry, chocolate, and green tea. all were awesome.
Like many other sushi places it is some what small. Very nice inside though with lots of wood furnishings.
They also have a happy hour that looks quite enticing :D

#1 sushi restaurant!

Saikoh!!
sugoi!!
author: RAy J.

description: The service was totally fast, efficient and friendly. And i know they use high grade fish as i can telll.  pricing was reasonable for being in dt are and food was just totally awesome! for its price, it deserve 5
author: chris l.

description:
Food is OK, decor is nonexistant, tables are glued to one another. But it was a fun experience no big deal just lunch..until the check arrived...I am a foreigner and I went there with a friend of mine who shares the same language... We discovered speechless that they had written the tip on our check!!!!! as opposed to our neighbor who was American and who filled out the amount herself the way it should be (remember the tables are very close to one another it was not hard to eyeball her check). This is flat out DISCRIMINATION to assume I am an ignorant tourist because I don't speak English!!! when I have been living here for 9 years...
I confronted the waitress who played dumb and was unapologetic. I will never go back there
author: Carpe D.

description: I went to this restaurant couple weeks ago, and had a very bad experience there as some of you might read it... today I have received a dirty message from colette p., I can see some of the previous reviewers did too... here is the message, "ay bit*h dont be tlakign sh*t about my moms restaurant. better not step into her place again before i fu*k you up. she works hard to run the da*n place and if u dont own a da*n restaurant dont be even talkign sh*t if you dont even know wassup about how u run a da*n place. if i see you, you done with. bit*h a*s c*nt." Please expect to receive this kind of message if you had a bad experience in this restaurant and gave them a "bad" review.
author: Bee T.

description:
slow service.

the gyoza from happy hour is probably the oiliest thing i've tasted in quite a while.

the quality of sashimi is very poor. and it is not cheap.

really dont have much good to say.
author: Danielle A.

description: Best sushi I've ever had. Our server didnt have the best grasp on the English language, but she was very pleasant. Awesome place!
author: Christopher S.

description: Lots of food at a great price. The sashimi is fresh, and the beef teriyaki is korean-style bbq beef. This is a pretty good deal for lunch in the fidi.
author: Celia L.

description: This wonderful little restaurant is right outside Chinatown and a true gem. If you are adventurous I highly recommend getting the "chef's special roll" we got 2 of them and both were amazingly delicious. (I posted pictures) The roll sizes are decently large, and the fish was fresh and tasty. If you are a salmon fiend like I am, there is a salmon lovers roll that is fantastic. Sit at the sushi bar if you can the chef's really nice.
author: flitter k.

description: My friend and I went here for lunch and it was all right.  We both ordered the nabeyaki with soba and it was tasty.  I thought the service was nice and the food came out quite quickly.  There's a good crowd for lunch, but the place isn't worth waiting for a table...there's too many lunch options in the area.
author: Lisa R.

description: Delicious sushi! Great rolls! Shashimi was so fresh! Great service. The giant roll was amazing!
author: Courtenay S.

description: Love it!!!! Love it !!!! Came with our kids and had a great meal. Bento boxes were the right choice for the kids.
author: kami A.

description: We came across this restaurant randomly and decided to check it out. It was pretty empty for a Saturday night at 7pm, so service very quick. We had a few appetizers, such as the tonkatsu and beef/chicken teriyaki, which were both pretty good. Bf got some sushi and we were both surprised at how thick the cuts of fish were. I would love to come back here for their lunch menu the next time I'm in town.
author: Marilyn V.

description: I felt a little rushed for some reason. I can't quite place it. I only had veggie rolls, but they were creative and yummy. It's a small place, but everyone seemed happy. (customers seemed happy, so of the wait staff, not so much.)
author: Courtney M.

description: The food was phenomenal.  However, I was very disappointed when I got the bill to find I was charged for the refills (it did not state the refills cost money on the menu).  So $4, for 2 cans of soda?  I can bring a whole 6 pack of soda in to sip on while I enjoy my meal for that price.
author: Skyler R.

description:
I've had better sushi in my life but this was decent . The fish was fresh, the rice was a good consistency. No frills menu. Great prices! Get the combo lunch, it's a great deal!

I'd definitely go back if I were in the area but I wouldn't make a special trip for it.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Just tried this place for the first time, right outside Chinatown. I had the Philadelphia, Florida, and Spicy Tuna rolls. All were really good and fresh. And I love the noodle salad thing that came with the lunch special!

Great place for fresh, inexpensive sushi.
author: J K.

description: had 4 things. house sake, gyoza,  spicy chicken and spicy tuna roll. everything was awesome.
author: krishan y.

description:
The server was very nice and pleasant. The draft beer was only $1.75 until 3pm. So far so good. But the food.... was less than acceptable. The potion of Chirashi was about a half of typical Japanese portion. The sashimi was the lowest quality I have ever seen in California. 
What happened to the Mikaku I used to know more than 10 years ago. I miss them.
author: Tadashi E.

description: Visited this past weekend. The food was good, but the service was horrible. First time I didn't leave a tip (it was that bad!)
author: Nica M.

description: Great sushi, and friendly staff.  The Chet's choice is a must have!
author: Will M.

description:
I miss the old Mikaku!  

I really want to love this place but I just don't think it's possible.  Today I went for lunch and ordered a bento set with tonkatsu and gyoza.  My tonkatsu was burned so badly it was black!  My miso tasted like tepid water.  The service was mediocre and the food definitely isn't worth a trip back.  I guess I should have just gone to Murracci's for curry instead.
author: Lauren L.

description:
All I can say is HAPPY HOUR!

My friend and I were killing some time walking to Chinatown and she saw the happy hour sign, yes...we went in because of that. 50% off all beers...pretty good. Needless to say, we got 2 pitchers of Sapporo for $12...YEEEE HAWWW!

We also ordered:
 - Edamame: Normal
 - Seaweed salad: Pretty good, wasn't cut with cheap seaweed so that was good
 - Dragon roll: Good size, good flavor, really pretty good.

Friendly and quick service. Good happy hour prices. I'll have to go back to input more on the food but from what I had, it was not bad.
author: Matt K.

description: Quickly becoming my favorite sushi joint in the neighborhood. The sushi quality is excellent and the owner girl is hilarious! Try the premium sake sampler, great way to learn about Sake's and the different tastes.
author: Travis R.

description: This place is YUM!  My husband was craving sushi so we decided to check out this spot.  I was really impressed with the amount of veggie rolls they offered - another reason I love San Francisco!  We had the seaweed salad and steamed spinach to start - both of which were very good and just the right amount of appetizer.  I ordered the veggie dragon roll with eggplant, avocado, and sweet potato - three of my favorite things!  It was delicious.  My husband ordered another one of their specialty rolls - dont' remember the name but it had salmon in it and he said it was very good.  The prices were decent, the rolls were 10 and 11 dollars each.  I will definitely visit this place again next time I am in the area.
author: Beenish K.

description: New ownership has dramatically improved the quality and service at Mikaku! Can't speak to the rolls but the sashimi has been consistent and fresh (even on the dreaded sushi on Sunday visit). Pricing is very reasonable and has a great neighborhoody feel despite being in the middle of Union Square.
author: John S.

description:
I know I don't go out nearly enough to be a good Yelper but I am glad I have this place to write about. This place was recommended to me by one of the very few people I trust in taste, and like always I got what he promised. 

I desired authentic Japanese food. Not sushi, which plagues San Francisco and sushi is good in itself but what I was specifically looking for was more into the depths of Japanese cuisine.

That being said, this is where I am going to say a few things about Japanese restaurants in the United States. At least 95% of them are catered for the American consumer. Proof? California rolls. So as I read all these negative reviews about this place, it makes me sad and at the same time wonder about the overall palate of the Americans. Not just in food, but the overall dining experience, including service and treatment.

What Americans don't realize is how Japanese restaurants are actually run in Japan, where the wait staff actually wait for your call (in many places, with a push of a button). Americans are obsessed with chugging down insane amounts of water, which is why they expect their waters to be constantly refilled, whereas in Japan your glass of water will probably last you the entire meal. In Japan they do not come to you every five minutes to ask whether the food is good, because really that is more annoying than polite. They will not bother you period unless you call them, and if you call them, it is to order more food or beer/sake, not a refill of water when your glass is still half full. But Americans expect it, and when they do not get it they regard it as bad service. Whereas in Japan, it is perfectly good service. So to give a bad review because of this is very miscredited, and it is hard not to get exasperated and yell out "shut up you spoiled brats".

About the sushi, again it is catered to Americans. You want cheap sushi, you got it. You order California rolls with your maguro nigiri and you expect the maguro to be of high quality. Sorry, that's just not going to happen anywhere. Do any of you know why the California roll was invented in the first place? I'm sure most of you would be offended. To order California rolls at a sushi restaurant is an insult to the tradition. To order a rock roll, a volcano roll, a spider roll, you're just digging your own grave. The California roll order is the deal breaker in automatically knowing whether the customer is serious about eating good Japanese food. To give a restaurant a bad review based on their California rolls is just silly.

For this place, the sushi counter is just there to satisfy the American expectation, that a Japanese restaurant is not a Japanese restaurant unless they serve sushi, i.e. California rolls.

I knew not to come here for sushi, when I walked in I did not expect sushi, yet I still sat at the counter, because that is where the head chef was. When the waitress asked if I will be having any sushi, I told her no thanks. 

I glanced at the menu, but I didn't really read the details. I knew that the things I wanted were not on the menu, and all I needed to do was talk with the head chef a little. This is my scheme for all good Japanese restaurants, to introduce myself to the head chef and let him know my knowledge of Japanese food and let him decide what I would like. I told him I wanted food from the kitchen, what he thought was good.

They all get a bit confused and awkward at first, since I am clearly an American Asian and I speak English. But usually they break down pretty quick as I ask for more and more food, and by the end mutual respect is formed. 

This is how to treat Japanese restaurants in America. It does you absolutely no good to bark at the chef about maGURro and haMAHchi niGIRri because you might as well be wearing a shirt with "baka gaijin" written all over it. The customer is not the king there, the head chef is. You show him respect, he will give you respect. If you can't pronounce it right, just say it in frickin English. 

Most of what I got is written on the white board, which is what you need to pay attention to because that's the place that lists the true Japanese dishes they serve. Lightly fried pumpkin with a bit of salt on the side, pan fried light duck meat, chawan mushi (steamed egg with soup), and homemade (hand cut!!) soba noodles. Does anybody know just how hard it is to make soba yourself? And the chef admitted to me it took him a long time to get it right.

The chawan mushi is one of the best I have had in San Francisco, the pumpkin is something you don't see often here, the duck is nice and fatty as it should be, and the soba is a great eye-opening experience after so many places that serve them right out of the package.

After I ate I sat and chatted with him for a long time, talking of food and of the nabe (hotpot) dish I will be back for next week (you must reserve this dish in advance in order for him to prepare it). He charges far less than what the food is worth, believe me.
author: Daria J.

description: It's closing soon, but before it does I want to take a moment to speak fondly of it. Okay here goes: a reliable choice for dinner when no particular inspiration struck us; a business needs a certain comfort with itself to be a go-to choice, and Mikaku managed that well.
author: Brian S.

description: A local recommended mikaku for lunch and I have been here every day since for my four day conference. Great food and reasonably priced. Sit at the sushi bar if you can. Great service!  Yoshi was the sushi chef who treated me best.
author: Tom O.

description: I was here several months ago and remembered the food to be better, but today's fish was just bits and pieces.  I came after the lunch hour, so they might have run out of the best pieces of tuna and yellow tail, but I felt let down.  I do like that they offer a complimentary roll, but I won't be back any time soon as it appears that consistency it is not at Mikaku.
author: Bo T.

description:
We stopped here before a friend's birthday. 

I ordered a Mikaku Special and my girlfriend ordered the 3 sushi roll deal. 
The food was just okay - nothing special. Tthe portions were really small, especially the teriyaki chicken. The tempura was cooked very well. The cost was on par with other Japanese restaurants but the quality of the food just wasn't there. Their ingredients didn't taste very fresh and the restaurant seats were dirty.

The service was average.
author: Brian W.

description:
as far as i've found to date, the best sushi in the fidi.  

friendly japanese owner and staff.

firmly made nigiri, with fresh fish and small rice, the way it's supposed to be.

simple rolls are tight so you're not left with a rice swamp in your shoyu dish.

reasonably priced.

no comparison to ghetto chinese sushi boats.
author: Reina M.

description:
FOOD POISONING!!!!  I was sick for two days after eating there.  I have never felt so miserable in my life.  I ate lunch there one day and I had a sneaking suspicion that something was a little off when eating but finished my meal.  That night I almost went to the hospital I was so sick.  I was curled up on the bathroom floor until 5 in the morning when i stopped vomiting.  The entire next day I was also sick (shaking, chills, upset stomach, unmentionable other symptoms).  

Eat here at your own risk!
author: Jaden V.

description: Their food is great, but service is horrible. I just had my second bad experience with calling in for takeout. They screw up the orders regularly and then don't offer any kind of compensation for waiting for a long time to get the food that is a wrong order anyway?! Seriously - bad customer service. AND, found a hair in my soup that took 30 minutes to get. Ridiculous.
author: AMIE L.

description: I would give them 5 stars, as they're one of the few really great sushi spots in the FiDi, but they got rid of the noodle salad after the revamp! So sad.
author: Sasha V.

description: Honestly, I have come to suspect that no one in America knows what the hell they are talking about when it comes to sushi and Japanese food.   It's so much easier to be detached or pass judgment--no one wants to be vulnerable and enthusiastic.  Well I'm enthusiastic about Mikaku. This place is as good as you could expect in the homeland for the price with delicious and generous servings that only go California in their vegetarian variety.  The location and decor are pleasant enough as well.  I take my Japanese family here and they are always happy to indulge in cheap, tasty, and authentic Japanese food.
author: Eartha K.

description: I really liked this place. Low key and great sushi (they get the rice right - critical!). Tempura and other stuff good too.
author: Donna S.

description:
i think this must be the first restaurant i went to because i read a yelp review.  what a sheep ive become.  =[

we came here on a wednesday night before a movie.  there was a table of two japanese men here.  and before we left another japanese couple.  maybe on a date?  so pretty quiet or slow night.  not sure what its like at lunch.  our waitress spoke fluent english and japanese so that was neat.

we ordered the handmade soba.  which u can only get cold by the way.  i wanted mine hot but the hot ones are not hand made. the simmered cod fish in miso broth.  nori/seaweed chazuke (rice in soup).  salmon onigiri (rice ball).  oshitashi (spinach).  my bf ordered sushi but i didnt have any of it.

the soba was good.  they give you the water the noodles were boiled in at the end which is supposed to be good for you.  but im not a big fan.  cod was good considering it was simmered and i thought it would fall apart.  bf said the hamachi was hard. rice dishes were good.

they have other things that look interesting too like duck and the kabocha/pumpkin.  maybe ill come back.  i dont know why i feel like it was epxnsive for what i got.  $60 for two people considering it was mostly rice.  or is that how expensive japanese food nowadays?  hmm
author: claudia y.

description:
Came here armed with a coupon and ordered plenty of sushi.  I actually expected it to still look like its former self (it's under new management), but I like the new look a lot better.  It looks very classy.  I used to come here for lunch sometimes, but the food definitely was poorer quality than it is now.  This time, the sushi was absolutely delicious.

I love rolls and the healthy portion I ordered really hit the spot.  The waitresses were really attentive and nice, as a bonus.
author: Sylvi Y.

description:
i must say, i really wanted to love this place.

it's 3 blocks from my office. im dying to find a good japanese restaurant near by.

the service is friendly. i got a free california roll for being an "early bird"

to start, the avocado in my free california roll was not ripe. crunchy. ever had crunchy avocado? 'nuff said.

my spicy tuna roll was not horrible, but the rice was dry and somehow it was very salty. the tempura was undercooked and really greasy. the oil smelled of fast food. the cold noodles were tasty, but nothing special. my teriyaki chicken was just aight, at least it was cooked. the dressing on the salad was a bit too mayo-ey. there were a couple of small flies checking out my food the whole time

but the tea was nice. i love a good green tea.

i went here on the suggestion of a coworker and i think i should go kick him now.

for $15 (after tip) i left hungry and feeling a bit ill.
author: Tala D.

description: Found this place after a busy day in Union Square, and while it's nothing uber-special, I would definitely come back. Although the service was a little jagged around the edges (at one point we had two waiters at our table, contradicting each other about an unlisted drink price, then both walked away without taking our order), the rolls were tasty and the prices were reasonable (especially for the happy hour menu, which they have even on Saturdays, 5-7pm). The fish was fresh, good flavorings particularly on the spicy rolls, and the presentation was very nice. My biggest complaint is that their California Roll uses imitation crab, which is a bummer since so too do all the special rolls that are built on top of this (probably 2/3 of the special rolls menu?) which is limiting if, like me, you're not a fan of that fake crab stuff :(
author: Hilary M.

description:
Really fresh sashimi.  Even my 12-year-old son, who usually won't eat fish, loved the hamachi.  He practically inhaled his spider roll - I didn't even get to try it.  Their spicy tuna is pretty spicy, which was a nice balance to the milder selections.
Nice decor.  Great location on Grant, around the corner from the Sutter Street elevator exit of Stockton/Sutter garage.  Will definitely go back.
author: Ever B.

description: This is one of our sushi lunch go-to places with the co-workers. I like the nigiri and roll lunch special. It's good price and the fish is fresh and tasty. Also you get tea with your meal which I always enjoy.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Don't waste your money or time.  Service was atrocious.  Food was mediocre.  It's a big city.  We failed to do our research before visiting and this was our just desserts.
author: Liz S.

description: This little sushi spot doesn't hit the spot. Its edible but I wouldn't recommend anyone going out of their way to check it out.  I wish I had been able to try this place before management changed.  I had Combo A and was disappointed.  Its too loud in there and the service set up is a mess.  I wish it had been better.  Should I be expecting a nasty email now?
author: Allison M.

description:
the perfect FiDi traditional Japanese lunch (right in front of chinatown gate).  Very reasonably priced chirashi for $11 with good rice, maguro, albacore, salmon, mackerel, and snapper.  unfortunately, at lunch, you can't order the whiteboard izakaya dinner items -- these look very good and interesting, including housemade soba, pumpkin, eggplant, skatewing, oyster, etc.
the katsu-don also was nicely done with the egg

sorry to hear that it's changed now as of 10/09
author: Rob C.

description: I have a sore throat and my friend is home sick with bronchitis. What makes us both happy? The buckwheat soba noodles in warm broth. Not really expensive but not cheap, kind of what you would expect for the area. It was a little unorganized trying to place an order to go, but it was ready quickly and it smelled so good it was hard to wait to eat until I got my sick friends' place!
author: Melissa W.

description: I went here yesterday for lunch and was shocked to see how much this place has changed! It is much "fancier" with clubby music playing in the background and a sign out front advertising "MK Sushi & Sake Happy Hour". No more Itou-san and his wife, they went back to Japan! Very sad. I sat at the counter and ordered "Sushi Combo Lunch A" which was maguro, ebi, hirame, unagi, kappa maki with miso soup and salad. Unfortunately the only thing that was half way decent was the kappa (cucumber) roll. All the sushi tasted very old and rubbery. The unagi was cold and hard. The hirame definitely tasted like it was way past its prime. The rice was not good either (again, cold) and there was hardly any wasabi in btwn rice and fish. The miso soup tasted like bleach (probably didn't rinse the bowl well when it was washed) and the iceberg lettuce salad was literally 5 pieces of brown, wilted, stalky pieces (dressing was good though). The service was very friendly, but so slow and forgetful. Many customers were getting impatient and irritated since everyone was in a hurry on their lunch break. The boss (at least who I think was the boss, behind the sushi counter) was trying his best to make sushi, chat with customers and manage the incompetent staff so he gets 4 stars. But unfortunately the food was so bad I'm not sure if I'll be back. I thought maybe it was just opening kinks they needed to work out, but I heard they've been open for 3 months now. They should be on top of their game at this point. Guess I'll be going to Doujima-an when I'm downtown. I do wish the new owners lots of luck though. They were very nice people.
author: lani P.

description: Although decent in taste, the presentation was dreadful. Sushi should have clean cuts and colorful. We ordered four rolls and an appetizer. Service was given if requested. The price was on par for the quality. The spicy tuna was the best tasting out of the entire meal.
author: kelly y.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this authentic, cozy Japanese restaurant - in Union Square, of all places! I was expecting a super tourist trap and was delighted to be proven wrong. The sashimi was very fresh and the udon (I chose the one with scrambled eggs - it comes with chicken as well) was really good...the soup was SO tasty. We also tried the spider roll, which was crammed with just-fried crab. Mikaku is reasonably priced - again, especially for a Union Square restaurant - and I will definitely come here again when I'm craving fresh sashimi.
author: Adrienne C.

description: this place was okay.  I should've ordered the udon.  the chirashi didn't look that fresh.
author: con c.

description: I didn't know it was possible to screw up Miso soup but this place managed it.The second to worst sushi I ever had in my life.  Should have gotten my cue from the empty restaurant. Never again.
author: roy l.

description: Located right across from Rouge & Blanc Wine Bar, this place is my new fav sushi restaurant in the city. I was told that ownership changed hands a couple weeks ago, and that the decor is a lot more modern now. I *really* really like this place. Fresh sashimi, and the rolls were put together with a ton of care. Plentiful portions of udon/soba noodles in eclectic dishware. Service is great. The owner personally waited on us, as well as a cute young (very polite) guy from Belarus, (who even came over to ask if I was cold, (because he wanted to offer a shawl to use while I dined)). OOOHHHH Sooooo cute!! Intimate, but casual setting, unpretentious, cozy and comfortable. Prices are reasonable for the quantity given. While we dined, they were playing a mixed CD with jams from the 90's. My friend and I couldn't help but smile at every song that came on. Can you say artists like: Jodeci, PM Dawn, de la Soul? Old school jams that brought back SO many memories! Can't wait to go back!
author: Rebecca S.

description: My first experience at Mikaku was absolutely fabulous!  The seaweed salad, and sashimi sampler were super fresh and delicious.  The wait staff was completely attentive and friendly.  Natasha  (owner) is a total sweetheart and really takes a lot of pride in the service and food, but doesn't neglect the importance of a fun, lively atmosphere.  I can't wait to go back again for lunch carry out later this week!
author: Heather H.

description: Just happened to walk by the place and decided to go have dinner with my gf. She had the Naguri 12 piece deluxe and she loved it.  We also had the soft shell crab and dumplings for appetizer. I had the beef tonduri ( I think).  Though the servings were small they were good. Service was excellent.  The female owner (we think she's the owner) was very attentive and helpful. The waiter wasn't a lot of help though as he wasn't sure what was on the menu and had to ask the cook each time.She had us try (for free) the house baked mussels with their special sauce and it was GREAT.  Never had that before. Wouldn't mind going back there next time we are in SF again.
author: Mar S.

description: I'm not sure if anything else could have gone wrong during my lunch at Mikaku. After my sister and I first placed our order of lunch box specials, we were told we apparently ordered wrong and should have followed some mysterious instructions and chosen items from different columns (not stated on the menu). Our soup did not arrive until right before our meal. The food was ok, but when we were done eating it took about ten minutes for the waitress to come clear our plate, and she took our water which we were still drinking! I gave her my credit card to pay the bill and when she returned for me to sign, my credit card wasn't in there. We tried to get their attention but were ignored, and my sister finally found my card on the floor by the kitchen. I do not recommend, and would not go back.
author: Jillian S.

description: Mikaku is a gem of a sushi restaurant in the city. The fish is always phenomenal and fresh, and the service is excellent. Everyone should stop in and try this sushi! I've started going weekly because it's such a positive dining experience. I brought m boyfriend in and he agreed it is by FAR some of the best sushi in the city!!  Go to Mikaku TODAY!!! :)
author: Lady L.

description: I would give this place a 4 star or even 5  for the good food, decent price, and ample menu option if it wasn't for the lack of customer service.  The two waitresses are so inattentive.  Your water or tea is not refilled unless you ask, but they will hand you your bill even if you have not asked for it and will also remove your dish without asking if you are done.  These are my two biggest pet peeves when eating out!
author: Jake G.

description: i thinks its under new management now cuz they dont have the free order of california rolls for the first 10 customers!
author: Patrick M.

description: Simply one of the few restaurants downtown that offers such great personal service! No where else do they cook sushi like Mikaku's where anything on the menu makes any bad mood melt away. Just planning on coming here makes me excited. All the waiters/waitresses are very personable and informative about the menu and definitely know what's best. Natasha really made our night this weekend by simply being awesome and showing us a great time. I have worked in the downtown area now for almost three years and have never appreciated anyone's business more. Whether it's a quick lunch trip or a late night sushi expo, this is the place to go for all sushi cravings.
author: Jay S.

description: came here for dinner last night, and i just got nabeyaki udon b/c it was cold out.  i want to try the handpulled soba that everyone raves about next time.  my friends got it, and it looked good.  i was told to only order off the white board, b/c that's where all the specials are.
author: Helen T.

description: this is one of my favorite japanese restaurants in the city!  it's really more of a traditional, homemade type of authentic japanese food.  i have been here around four times and never ordered the sushi.  instead, i ordered food on the menu and on the board.  it's definitely not a fancy restaurant, but good for good old fashioned japanese home cooking.
author: Pelina C.

description: Ok...you've got $10, feel like Japanese food, and it's 11:15am, and if you happen to be one with a hearty appetite, well, then... run to Mikaku. Like the other reviews, this is not fancy fare, but it's no Todai either.  The 11:15am part you ask?  Well, if you're one of the first 10 customers that order $7 or more, then you get a free order of california roll.  (Note: if you order the $6.95 udon, you don't qualify.. literally, it's $7... order a diet coke or something!).  My lunch buddies and I go here every so often... the soba (you can't do soba bad!) is fulfilling on a warm day, and the nabeyaki udon keeps you in good spirits on the chilly SF days.  The sushi you ask... well, I won't take my chances so I can't give fair judgement on that... the portions look decent but... let me know how it tastes when you order it.  The waitstaff... well, they've gotten to know me and my timely 11:28 arrival... so they are kind.  All in all, I know you can do a lot worse.
author: Dale K.

description: i absolutely love this place.  we had a big meeting here and we've tried just about all the sashimi dishes they had on the menu. and they have the freshest sashimi!!i would definitely go back for their uni and ama-ebi... oh so delicious!  their tasteful presentation and the friendly service have made this trendy place one of my favorite sushi-stops in the city!
author: lis k.
